issue.title: Add alter implementation
issue.body:
Not sure if this is the best implementation but it works like the regular `Map` version, and I don't think it should have worse asymptotics. 

Can look at adding a test suite if that would be useful.

commits.message: enough stuff that we could start using a neural net in place of dumbEvaluation... I think

issue.title: BatchNorm isn't working correctly
issue.body:
It appears that the batchNormWeight and batchNormBias are being updated to be equal to what I'd expect the runningVar and runningMean to be.

```
BatchNorm {batchNormWeight = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}, batchNormBias = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2]}, runningMean = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2], runningVar = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}
```

It think the `at::batch_norm` api isn't doing what's expected.

I made a repro https://github.com/tom-huntington/batch-norm-repro
```
main = do
    batch_norm <- sample $ BatchNormSpec 1
    print batch_norm
    a <- randIO' [2,1]
    print a
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float a
    let b = batchNormForward batch_norm True 0.1 0 a
    print b
    print batch_norm
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float b
```

comment.body: Ah, nice! Is that in hasktorch somewhere already? I don't see it in [the index](https://hasktorch.github.io/doc-index-M.html); or perhaps you're proposing adding it, in which case I think that's a great idea.

issue.title: BatchNorm isn't working correctly
issue.body:
It appears that the batchNormWeight and batchNormBias are being updated to be equal to what I'd expect the runningVar and runningMean to be.

```
BatchNorm {batchNormWeight = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}, batchNormBias = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2]}, runningMean = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2], runningVar = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}
```

It think the `at::batch_norm` api isn't doing what's expected.

I made a repro https://github.com/tom-huntington/batch-norm-repro
```
main = do
    batch_norm <- sample $ BatchNormSpec 1
    print batch_norm
    a <- randIO' [2,1]
    print a
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float a
    let b = batchNormForward batch_norm True 0.1 0 a
    print b
    print batch_norm
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float b
```

comment.body:
Hm. Will this still modify one of the input `Tensor`s? If so, I guess I'd find that pretty surprising -- I think that mostly doesn't happen elsewhere in the library. They probably need to be in an `IORef`, or copied, or something.

I put together an implementation [here](https://github.com/dmwit/nurse-sveta/blob/reboot/src/Dr/Mario/Torch.hs#L110-L196) that may be of interest to some people, though admittedly it is not via bindings to the `libtorch` code. But, it does have the advantage of being for the typed API (so the dimensions of the inputs is clarified), and of working cleanly with convolutional nets a la pytorch's `BatchNorm2d` (and `1d`, `3d` via shape polymorphism).

issue.title: BatchNorm isn't working correctly
issue.body:
It appears that the batchNormWeight and batchNormBias are being updated to be equal to what I'd expect the runningVar and runningMean to be.

```
BatchNorm {batchNormWeight = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}, batchNormBias = IndependentTensor {toDependent = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2]}, runningMean = Tensor Float [1] [ 3.8708e-2], runningVar = Tensor Float [1] [ 0.9001   ]}
```

It think the `at::batch_norm` api isn't doing what's expected.

I made a repro https://github.com/tom-huntington/batch-norm-repro
```
main = do
    batch_norm <- sample $ BatchNormSpec 1
    print batch_norm
    a <- randIO' [2,1]
    print a
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float a
    let b = batchNormForward batch_norm True 0.1 0 a
    print b
    print batch_norm
    print $ sumDim (Dim 0) KeepDim Float b
```

comment.body: Besides the behavior problem described, there needs to be more `IO`s in types somewhere. It shouldn't be possible to get two different results from `show batch_norm` at two different points in the program.

issue.title: cabal repl should turn on the default extensions
issue.body: If I specify `default-extensions` in my cabal file, that's likely because those are frequently needed (or wanted) when playing with things in that component. Since the primary thing you do in `cabal repl` is play with things in a component, you tend to frequently want those same extensions turned on in the ghci session (or at least, *I* tend to frequently want that). I can turn them on myself, of course, as I discover I need them, but it would be nice for `cabal` to do it for me.

commits.message: put position evaluation in its own OS thread
allow search configurations to be modified at runtime

MVar -> TVar

The vast majority of the time, the inter-thread comms we're doing has
one writer and one reader. That should be pretty much ideal for TVar, so
let's switch.
hs-source-dirs could have multiple directories on a single line

issue.title: MonadFail instance (feature request)
issue.body:
It would be very handy to have a `MonadFail` instance that `retry`s. As a minimal motivating example, consider:

    pop :: TVar [a] -> STM a
    pop v = do
        a:as <- readTVar v
        writeTVar v as
        return a

With a `MonadFail` instance, this is a very convenient way of writing a transaction that waits until there's a value available in the stack.

More generally, such an instance would allow one to write a transaction as if all your favorite patterns matched, and the transaction would then efficiently block until it's so.

this preprocessor thing is really, really fiddly, gross
the UI can have a little AI, as a treat
this quitting logic is surprisingly intricate
add a utility function like normalize but for Statistics
